metadata.title: Automation of Sentiment Analysis & Topic Modeling on Py-Spark & SparkNLP (using Twitter big-data) | by Raj Karansinh | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Automation of Sentiment Analysis & Topic Modeling on Py-Spark & SparkNLP (using Twitter big-data)
metadata.description: Over the past decade, usage of political social-media (mainly Twitter) accounts has skyrocketed. Many political leaders (& sometimes their families) are using Twitter as a preeminent mode of…

all_paragraphs: “Elections nowadays aren’t the same, social-media have changed them a lot!” — Oh yes, me.

Over the past decade, usage of political social-media (mainly Twitter) accounts has skyrocketed. Many political leaders (& sometimes their families) are using Twitter as a preeminent mode of communication with their citizenry. However, this has led to some interesting problems. Not only American elections but also the recent elections of the world’s largest democracy, India, was also accused to be ‘Biased’ due to social media influence (check out this article by ‘The Washington Post’ to get what I mean here). The bias, mainly in the form of polarized ‘public sentiments’, was injected by distorting the fragile fabric of social-media.

Thinking of American politics & Twitter, chances are President Donald J. Trump comes to your mind. Ever since the year 2015, when Trump launched his political campaign, he became infamous for his so-called negative, derogatory & somewhat provoking tweets. Give him, 280 character limit, he’ll translate it to a package consisting of the whole spectrum of emotions, sentiments, facts, and opinions (check out this article by ‘The New York Times’ to know the bulk of tweets which he plays with). Even Vox (famous American news and opinion website), in one of its articles, confirms that Trump tweets a lot, & the quantum is really out there.

All of the above facts, combined with my advanced-analytics knowledge made me think — can I develop a Live App that could keep a track on the social-media behavior of candidates fighting for the United States Presidential election, 2020?
It took me around a month of my summertime to completely answer my above question with the following:
While working on this project, I specifically oriented my work, around the following questions keeping two electoral candidates in mind (Mr. Donald J. Trump & Mr. Joe Biden):

My first step to answering the above questions was to gather the appropriate data & storing them in a database. For understanding the candidate level analysis (questions 1,2 & 4), I needed information related to the specific candidate. And for the user level analysis(user sentiments — question 3), I needed general tweet data referring to candidates under survey.

To fetch the candidate level data, I decided to use official Tweeter’s Developer API, over a python native ‘Tweepy Package’. While working on the newly fetched natural text data, I also used a cleaning function (‘clean_tweets’) as mentioned in the below code snippet:

As per the official guidelines, Twitter API allows only 300 tweets every 3 hours. Hence, this much amount of data won’t allow me to do proper sentiment analysis over user-level data. To circumvent this limit, after doing a bit of research, I decided to use the Optimized Get Old Tweets 3 wrapper. It allowed me to fetch historic tweets related to candidates. Although, the maximum tweets GOT allows every hit is 10,000. Hence, I attached 15 mins of sleep cycle once every hit.

Since I planned for automating the models, and considering the daily quantum of 20k+ tweet data fetch, I was looking for an open-source RDBMS to store my data. I connected my data to PostgreSQL using python’s ‘psycopg2’ library, where I’m storing candidate level as well as user level data, both separately in different tables.

As I planned to update my App-Data daily, I was looking for an NLP solution that could allow me the fastest & yet more accurate framework for ‘Sentiment Analysis’ & ‘Topic-Modeling’. After a few days of research, I found a big-data framework developed by John Snow Labs. The framework is known as ‘Spark NLP’. It is built on top of Apache Spark ML. It provides simple, performant & accurate NLP annotations for machine learning pipelines that scale easily in a distributed environment. Spark NLP comes with 220+ pretrained pipelines and models in more than 46+ languages. It supports state-of-the-art transformers such as BERT, XLNet, ELMO, ALBERT, and Universal Sentence Encoder that can be used seamlessly in a cluster. It also offers Tokenization, Part-of-Speech Tagging, Named Entity Recognition, Dependency Parsing, Spell Checking, Multi-class text classification, Multi-class sentiment analysis, and many more NLP tasks.

Those who have used py-spark would’ve been knowing the challenges of implementing a py-spark environment on my local machine. After multiple revisions of installing & un-installing various versions of py-spark, I finally found the right combination of ‘pyspark 2.4.4’ & java version ‘JDK v.8.0’ that worked perfectly fine with spark NLP. Once I installed & set up the paths for my pyspark, I installed the latest version of ‘sparkNLP’. Further, after installing spark & sparkNLP, I started a spark session using sparkNLP (you can also start a custom session using spark itself) & imported necessary SQLContext that might be required for handling the spark data-frames in further stages of model building.

Once the environment was set, I built a master function that takes my previously built pandas data frame as input & provides Text Length along with Sentiment Score of every tweet. The function is built using the Pipeline concept similar to many other machine learning libraries, which consists of two major components such as Estimators (estimate data and train models) and Transformers (transform data and apply models) which are defined as Annotators. While building the pipeline, annotation formatting is kept very specific, that matches to ‘annotating guidelines’, as they take input and output data in very specific format. Hence, it becomes very important to maintain the flow of pipeline built in a specific sequence. For example, In the documentation of Spark NLP for Tokenizer, you can see that this annotator accepts only input data of annotator type DOCUMENT and outputs data of a TOKEN type. Thus, the correct type that comes in and out of the annotators in Spark NLP pipeline is to be specially taken care of.
Following is the flow & basic functions of pipeline elements used for my analysis:
i. ‘DocumentAssembler’ Transformer: Formats the raw input text data for our first annotator
ii. ‘Tokenizer’ Annotator: Identifies tokens with tokenization open standards
iii. ‘Normalizer’ Annotator: Clean the data and perform lower-casing
iv. ‘LemmatizerModel’ Annotator: Brings all words in the data to its lemma (base form)
vi. ‘NGramGenerator’ Annotator: Incorporates n-grams into our NLP pipeline
vii. ‘PerceptronModel’ Annotator: Uses a pre-built POS tagging model to avoid irrelevant combinations of part-of-speech (POS) tags in our n-grams
viii. ‘Finisher’ Transformer: Converts the final annotator output into a usable format

Once the above pipeline is fitted (code line 1 : 78) on the input data, I utilized a pre-trained pipeline ‘analyze_sentimentdl_use_twitter’ to determine the sentiment scores of my Finisher output (code line 80 : 85).

Finally, once the custom pipeline is fitted & sentiment scores are calculates, all the original columns are joined on ‘id_tmp’ column to the new ‘sentscores’ column (code line 95: 98), and a final output is generated. Once the Spark data-frame is made, it is again converted into pandas data-frame for user usability (code line 107: 120)
The out-put of the above function looked like following (for every data file passed):

Since, SparkNLP alone doesn’t support text vectorization, I utilized a combination of SparkNLP & Py-spark ML features to built a LDA model. I used cleaned n-grams & unigrams developed from SparkNLP pipeline as an input to ‘CountVectorizer’ model (helps us calculate TF-IDF term frequency-inverse term frequency / word importance) of pyspark ml library. Further, the TF-IDF output is used to train a pyspark ml’s LDA clustering model (most popular topic-modeling algorithm).

To automate all the above steps, I utilized python framework in conjunction of windows command-prompt. I connected all the functions & their python script in a sequential order resulting in a master .py file. This master python script was liked to local python.exe using a windows batch (.bat) file. And, finally the batch file was put on an auto-execution mode using windows task-scheduler. Also, with appropriate print-line text commands in python, I managed to get the ‘execution-report’ in a .txt file, everyday when the code is executed. A snippet of execution-report is as follows:
To take advantage of my opensource twitter (Election2020) data & for more detailed script on topic modelling pipeline with Spark in Python, check out my github code repo.
Check my Live-App (Tableau-Public), showcasing all the above analysis on one platform.
Find more of me on my LinkedIn, E-Mail, & Personal-Portfolio.
A Data Science Enthusiast, who’s not planning to activate human neurons with electrodes, certainly not!
